properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall amounts possible in snow squalls on Friday. Total snowfall: generally 2 to 4 cm, with locally 10 cm or more possible in snow squalls. Time span: early Friday to Friday night. Remarks: A blowing snow advisory is already in effect for poor visibility expected later tonight into early Friday. This alert is also in effect due to the possibility of locally heavy accumulations in snow squalls on Friday. Snow squalls will taper to flurries on Friday night. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-26T17:32:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-26T01:33:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1998690891.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 65 will continue today. These extreme wind chill values will persist into Friday and then moderate by evening. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense Pacific frontal system brought near 20 cm of snow to Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass today. Additional snow accumulations of 10 to 15 cm can be expected before the snow tapers off to a few flurries tomorrow morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwest winds 70 km/h gusting to 90 Friday. A ridge of high pressure will build off Vancouver Island on Friday and produce very strong winds over southern Strait of Georgia. Over Southern Gulf Islands and areas of Metro Vancouver near the Strait of Georgia, winds will increase to northwest 70 km/h gusting to 90 early Friday morning. Winds will abate somewhat late Friday morning but will remain strong through early Saturday morning. ### Gusty winds can damage soft shelters, tents and awnings at outdoor events. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-26T15:58:05-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds gusting up to 110 km/h will continue early this evening before easing later tonight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill values have moderated in Naujaat, but are expected to return again tonight. Temperatures near minus 40 combined with northerly winds of 15 to 20 km/h will bring a return of extreme wind chill values of minus 55 and colder to Naujaat overnight. These extreme wind chill values will moderate Friday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h are bringing blizzard conditions with near zero visibility in blowing snow to communities in the southern Kivalliq. These blizzard conditions will gradually improve overnight. Overnight, along with the blizzard conditions, temperatures will drop to minus 40 and lower in the southern Kivalliq. These frigid temperatures combined with the gusty northwest winds will give extreme wind chill values of minus 60 to minus 65. These extreme cold values will last through to Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. A cold arctic airmass will settle over parts of northern Manitoba beginning Thursday night. This cold airmass will cause overnight wind chill values to reach extreme cold criteria of -45 and colder. These extreme wind chill values will moderate somewhat during the day, but will return over the next few nights. Extreme cold warnings will likely end Sunday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-26T13:24:53-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Strongest wind gusts: northwesterly between 80 and 90 km/h. Time span: tonight and Friday. Remarks: Strong winds are expected to develop later tonight and persist through Friday. Winds will combine with fresh snow to cause very poor visibility in blowing snow. Snow is expected to transition to flurries and snow squalls overnight tonight and continue all day Friday. However, since the winds will still be quite strong, visibility will likely remain poor throughout the day. Conditions will improve Friday night as the flurries and snow squalls begin to taper off. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-26T17:31:49-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Strongest wind gusts: northwesterly between 60 and 70 km/h. Time span: overnight tonight into Friday. Remarks: Strong winds are expected to develop tonight which will combine with fresh snow to cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will be at their worst overnight tonight and during the early morning hours on Friday. Winds will diminish slightly Friday morning, but it is unclear whether widespread blowing snow will continue to be a problem throughout the day due to persistent flurries and snow squalls. Conditions will improve either during the day on Friday, or potentially as late as Friday night as flurries and snow squalls begin to taper off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected to develop. Under the snow squall, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. An unstable airmass combined with a trough of low pressure will produce blustery conditions with localized whiteouts over the Avalon Peninsula late Friday afternoon and Friday evening. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for brief but intense bursts of heavy snow producing near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for overnight and Friday. An intense band of snow associated with the passage of a cold front is expected to move across Far Northern Ontario on Friday. This band of snow may extend from Winisk River to Sachigo Lake early Friday morning and is expected to move southward throughout the day, reaching Lansdowne House to Cat Lake by Friday evening. A total snowfall accumulation up to 10 cm is possible. Hazardous travel conditions are expected due to near zero visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow. Consider post-poning non essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. A cold arctic airmass will settle over parts of northern Manitoba beginning Thursday night. This cold airmass will cause overnight wind chill values to reach extreme cold criteria of -50 and colder. These extreme wind chill values will moderate somewhat during the day, but will return over the next few nights. Extreme cold warnings will likely end Sunday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 65 will continue today. These extreme wind chill values will persist into Friday and then moderate by evening. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
